checklists.title: Infrastructure - NIST SP 800-53 Rev5
checklists.description: Comprehensive security assessment checklist based on NIST Special Publication 800-53 Revision 5 security and privacy controls applicable to infrastructure environments. Covers Access Control (AC), Audit and Accountability (AU), Configuration Management (CM), Contingency Planning (CP), Identification and Authentication (IA), System and Communications Protection (SC), and System and Information Integrity (SI) control families. This checklist provides actionable assessment questions to evaluate infrastructure compliance with federal information system security requirements.

items.question: Is there a documented access control policy that defines authorized users, groups, and roles for all infrastructure systems, and are individual accounts managed through a formal account lifecycle process including creation, activation, modification, review, disabling, and removal (AC-2)?
items.expectedEvidence: Access control policy document, account provisioning/deprovisioning procedures, and recent user access review reports.
items.autoTaskTitle: Review infrastructure account management process (AC-2)

items.question: Is the principle of least privilege enforced across infrastructure systems, ensuring that users and service accounts are only authorized for the access necessary to accomplish their assigned tasks (AC-6)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Evaluate least privilege enforcement on infrastructure (AC-6)

items.question: Are unsuccessful login attempts to infrastructure systems limited by locking accounts or delaying subsequent attempts after a defined number of consecutive failures, and are administrators notified of repeated failures (AC-7)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Verify unsuccessful login attempt handling on infrastructure (AC-7)

items.question: Are remote access connections to infrastructure management interfaces authorized, monitored, and controlled through encrypted tunnels (VPN, SSH) with multi-factor authentication (AC-17)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Assess remote access controls for infrastructure management (AC-17)

items.question: Are auditable events defined for infrastructure systems, including logins, privilege escalation, configuration changes, and system start/stop events, and are audit records generated with sufficient detail (user identity, timestamp, source, outcome) (AU-2, AU-3)?
items.expectedEvidence: List of auditable events per system type, sample audit log entries showing required fields, and audit policy configuration exports.
items.autoTaskTitle: Verify auditable event definitions and log content (AU-2/AU-3)

items.question: Is sufficient audit log storage capacity allocated for infrastructure systems, and are mechanisms in place to alert personnel and take defined actions (overwrite oldest, halt system) when storage capacity is at risk of being exceeded (AU-4, AU-5)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Check audit log storage capacity and overflow handling (AU-4/AU-5)

items.question: Are audit records from infrastructure systems reviewed, analyzed, and correlated on a defined frequency to identify inappropriate or unusual activity, and is there an automated mechanism (SIEM) to support this analysis (AU-6)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Evaluate audit review and analysis process for infrastructure (AU-6)

items.question: Are audit records protected from unauthorized access, modification, and deletion, including use of integrity verification mechanisms and centralized log collection to a hardened log management system (AU-9)?
items.expectedEvidence: Centralized log server configuration, access control lists on log storage, and integrity verification mechanism documentation.
items.autoTaskTitle: Verify audit record protection mechanisms (AU-9)

items.question: Is a baseline configuration established and maintained for each type of infrastructure system (servers, network devices, hypervisors), and are deviations from the baseline documented and approved (CM-2)?
items.expectedEvidence: Baseline configuration documents or templates for each infrastructure type, version-controlled configuration repositories, and deviation approval records.
items.autoTaskTitle: Review baseline configurations for infrastructure systems (CM-2)

items.question: Is a formal configuration change control process implemented for infrastructure, requiring analysis of security impact, approval, documentation, and testing of changes before deployment to production (CM-3)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Assess configuration change control process for infrastructure (CM-3)

items.question: Are infrastructure systems configured in accordance with security configuration guidelines (e.g., CIS benchmarks, DISA STIGs), with the most restrictive mode consistent with operational requirements, and are settings monitored for compliance (CM-6)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Evaluate security configuration settings compliance (CM-6)

items.question: Are only essential services, ports, protocols, and software functions enabled on infrastructure systems, with all unnecessary capabilities disabled or removed to reduce the attack surface (CM-7)?
items.autoTaskTitle: Verify least functionality configuration on infrastructure (CM-7)

items.question: Is a contingency plan developed for infrastructure systems that identifies essential missions and business functions, recovery objectives (RTO/RPO), restoration priorities, roles, and responsibilities (CP-2)?
items.expectedEvidence: Infrastructure contingency plan document with defined RTO/RPO, restoration priorities, contact lists, and last review/update date.

checklists.title: Cluster - NSA/CISA Kubernetes Hardening Guide v1.2
checklists.description: Comprehensive security checklist based on the NSA/CISA Kubernetes Hardening Guidance v1.2 (March 2022). This guide was jointly published by the National Security Agency and the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency to provide hardening recommendations for Kubernetes environments. Covers pod security including non-root execution, immutable containers, and privilege restrictions; network separation with default-deny policies and encrypted communications; authentication and authorization through RBAC, OIDC integration, and service account hardening; audit logging configuration and analysis; cluster upgrading and patch management; vulnerability scanning for images and configurations; supply chain risk management for container images; and threat detection through runtime monitoring, anomaly detection, and incident response integration.
